Project Description  The  Education  Sector  Reform  Project  (ESRP)  will  support  the 
  Government’s reform priorities in primary (grades 1–4) and general 
  secondary  education  (grades  5–11).  It  will  comprise  three 
  components: (i) education system efficiency and management, (ii) 
  equitable access and completion, and (iii) quality improvement. A 
  top-down  approach  to  strengthening  capacity  at  the  Ministry  of 
  Education (MOE) to enhance efficiency, relevance, and equity in 
  primary  and  general  secondary  education,  and  a  bottom-up 
  approach to strengthening schools and district (raion) departments 
  of education in five pilot districts, will help MOE to strike a greater 
  balance between central and local functions. The project focus on 
  strengthening  the  education  management  information  system 
  (EMIS)  is  expected  to  improve  annual  planning  and  budgeting 
  critical to targeting resources to priority reforms and addressing 
  inequities. This is also expected to significantly enhance MOE’s 
  capacity to monitor progress of reforms and respond to emerging 
  needs. 
   
Rationale  Tajikistan’s education system is under significant threat following (i) 
  independence  and  cessation  of  large  subsidies  from  the  former 
  Soviet Union, (ii) prolonged civil strife that caused physical damage 
  to  an  estimated  20%  of  the  school  facilities,  and  (iii)  sharply 
  reduced financing to education resulting from an overall downturn in 
  the economy. The Government is now committed to reverse the 
  trend  with  increasing  support  from  several  external  funding 
  agencies.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to  institutionalize  systemic 
  reforms to make primary and general secondary education more 
  affordable, efficient, relevant, and equitable within a coherent and 
  affordable national education development framework (NEDF). The 
  Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided emergency-type physical 
  reconstruction  under  a  social  sector  rehabilitation  project  and 
  recognizes the need to undertake reforms gradually, through a well-
  informed and participatory process. The ESRP will combine top-
  down and bottom-up approaches in close collaboration with other 
  development  partners  under  MOE  leadership  to  systematically 
  address urgent reform priorities.

Objective and Scope  The main objective of the ESRP is to support MOE in developing 
  and  initiating  a  prioritized,  costed  NEDF  to  improve  efficiency, 
  equity, and quality of primary and general secondary education. 
  The  ESRP  will  emphasize  system  efficiency  and  management 
  improvement required throughout the education system in order to 
  make the education system more affordable and sustainable. The 
  ESRP will strengthen policy and planning capacity, encompassing 
  key  aspects  of  management  efficiency  (pedagogical  renewal, 
  financial management, and management reorganization). Improved 
  efficiency in these system elements will support enhanced access 
  and completion and improved quality. 
   
  The  ESRP  will  support  MOE  at  the  national  level  to  manage 
  education reform, and at the district level it will support five pilot 
  districts  for  school  improvement.  The  ESRP  will  have  a  direct 
  positive  impact  on  Tajikistan’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  by 
  improving  equitable  access  to  and  completion  of  better  quality 
  primary  and  general  secondary  education  and  improved  gender 
  balance in school participation in the five pilot districts.

(v) support monitoring and evaluation at the MOE. The TA will serve

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Tajikistan for the Education Sector Reform Project. The report also describes proposed 
technical assistance (TA) for strengthening planning and policy dialogue for education reform, 
and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by 
the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis  
2.  Following  cessation  of  economic  transfers  from  the  former  Soviet  Union  after 
independence in 1991, ethnic pressures contributed to a civil war that began in 1992 and lasted 
until 1997. Macroeconomic conditions worsened until 1997 when the economy started showing 
signs of recovery. Real gross domestic product (GDP) in 2002 was 60% of that in 1991. GDP 
per capita in 2001 was $162. Inflation, although lower than in the early 1990s, is still high, while 
real wages have decreased significantly since 1991. The aftermath of civil war, together with 
economic depression, has put more than 80% of the population below the national poverty line.  
 
3.  The  Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  Paper  (PRSP),1  endorsed  by  the 
parliament  in  June  2002,  sets  out  efficient  and  fair  provision  of  basic  social  services  to 
vulnerable  groups  as  an  approach  to  reducing  poverty.  The  Government's  medium-term 
strategy has been set in line with the poverty reduction strategy under its poverty partnership 
agreement with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in December 2002. The medium-term 
strategy stipulates that, for social sectors, ADB and the Government will focus on improving 
social service delivery to vulnerable groups and rationalizing social sector expenditures to 
ensure equitable access to quality education and health services. The Millennium Development 
Goals (MDGs) for 2015 form the key basis for the Government to monitor performance targets. 
The project framework in Appendix 1 provides key project targets. 
 
4.  The education system is the responsibility of the Ministry of Education (MOE) and is 
administered through a network of education departments in each of three regions (oblasts), as 
well as in Dushanbe, in the Regions of Republican Subordination (RSS), and in the districts 
(raion). Compulsory basic education is 9 years, reduced from 11 years in 1996 due to resource 
constraints. It is free, as per the constitution, and consists of 4 years of primary (grades 1–4) 
and 5 years of lower secondary (grades 5–9). Upper secondary comprises grades 10 and 11. 
Technical and vocational education and training is available after grade 9 (3 or 4 years) or after 
grade 11 (2 years). Public and private institutions provide tertiary education, with increasing cost 
recovery at both types of institutions.     
 
5.  Tajikistan has a rapidly growing population, with children under 17 years old comprising 
almost 50% of the total population of 6.3 million in 2000. The fertility rate—which was 5.0 in 
1990 and declined to 3.7 in 2000—remains the highest in Central Asia, and the population risks 
doubling every 20 years. Primary and general secondary education will have an additional 
850,000  students  by  2015,  and  social  services  must  be  ready  to  accommodate  a  rapidly 
growing population.

6.  Tajikistan  is  committed  to  achieving  the  MDGs  as  stipulated  in  the  PRSP.  The 
Government has pledged to reduce poverty incidence from 83% of the population in 1999 to 
58% by 2010 and improve the coverage of primary education from 78% in 2000 (a decline from 
over 90% in 1991) to 90% in 2015. The elimination of gender disparity in primary and general 
secondary education, mainly in upper secondary (grades 10 and 11), may be possible only by 
2010 or later. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
7.  Tajikistan inherited a highly centralized education system with a well-developed network 
of educational institutions, well-trained and -qualified teachers, almost universal access to and 
gender balance in compulsory basic education, and almost universal literacy (Appendix 2). 
Educational indicators were comparable with middle-income countries. These achievements are 
now threatened. 
 
8.  Declining Opportunities for Education. Following independence, declining resources 
and rising poverty have harmed the education system. Budget allocations to sustain the sector 
have been constrained, as has the demand for education, as represented by the opportunity 
costs of participation and poor employment opportunities. Enrollment in preschool and TVET 
has collapsed, but increased 19% from 1991 to 2001 in primary and general secondary to more 
than 1.5 million. This comes in spite of a decline in the gross enrollment ratio2 in basic education 
from 94.9% in 1990 to less than 84.3% in 2000. Gender imbalance is emerging particularly at 
the upper secondary level, with the proportion of girls declining from 49% in 1991 to 38% in 
2001. While enrollment has declined in primary education, actual attendance may be even 
lower. Many qualified teachers have left the profession because of very low salaries. Many 
students do not have textbooks or learning materials, and school buildings were badly damaged 
from the civil war and poor maintenance. More than 40% of parents have told surveys they are 
dissatisfied with education quality.3 The current generation in Tajikistan is at risk of receiving a 
poorer education than the previous one. 
 
9.  Need for a Coherent Vision and Strategy for Equitable, Sustainable Education. 
Since independence in 1991, a significantly reduced budget has been inadequate to sustain a 
highly developed education system. The PRSP proposes new measures to address challenges 
facing the sector. Tajikistan envisaged some decentralization in its new Law on Education 
(1994), but this strategy was largely employed to shift financial responsibility downward to local 
governments and parents who lack commensurate capacity, conceptual clarity, or resources. 
The Government wants to introduce a new financing system, involve local governments and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), improve quality through various measures, and make 
appropriate legal changes and amendments. The Government needs to develop a coherent, 
realistic vision and strategy given that the financial needs of the sector are not affordable within 
the current economic context. 
 
10.  Weak  Information  Base  and  Poor  Capacity  to  Prioritize  Systemic  Reform  and 
Address Inherent Inequities. MOE recognizes gaps in the information systems that support 
education  planning,  such  as  the  lack  of  information  on  learner  performance.  For  planning 
purposes, MOE has access only to broad averages on attendance and distribution of education 
inputs. While it is possible to analyse resource distribution across districts, it is not easy to

school principals and parents’ committees; indeed, few such programs are available. Data 
exists within MOE but is not integrated for coherent strategies or plans.  
 
11.  Because an integrated education management information system (EMIS) and adequate 
district-based information systems are lacking, it is difficult to ascertain whether education is 
equitably  provided  across  or  within  districts.  Although  there  is  substantial  circumstantial 
evidence of inequities, these are difficult to quantify. If little is known about inequities in terms of 
educational inputs, less is known about variations in learning outcomes. It is therefore difficult, if 
not impossible, to plan for increased equity or quality.  
 
12.  Inadequate  and  Inequitable  Opportunities  for  Teaching  and  Learning.  The 
education  system  that  was  conceived  and  developed  for  a  socialist  society  is  now  under 
pressure  to  adapt  to  a  market-based,  internationally  competitive  society.  The  teaching 
profession is unattractive because of low salaries, poor working conditions, and a lack of career 
opportunities. The overall teacher-to-student ratio of 1:15,4 average workload of 14–18 hours 
per  week,  and  single-subject  specialization  of  teachers  in  grades  5–11  make  the  system 
inefficient and expensive, and it absorbs resources that could be used to improve teacher 
salaries or provide more textbooks. 
 
13.  MOE made efforts after independence, most recently in 2002, to add new subjects to the 
curriculum and, in particular, to build national identity. However, the already heavy course load 
has increased further with the introduction of new subjects. In some cases, the new curriculum 
requires specialization to start from grade 5 instead of grade 9, as in the past. The curriculum 
must be made more relevant to the issues dominating Tajikistan's current social, political, and 
educational development, such as the movement toward a market economy; a transparent, 
democratic, and just society; attempts to improve system efficiency; and a focus on the quality 
of learning outcomes in schools. There is an urgent need to bring efficiency into both the 
curriculum development system and the actual curriculum through further reform focused on 
learning  outcomes.  Curriculum  development  is  currently  coordinated  by  the  Department  of 
Science, which has relied on ad-hoc groups and is fragmented as a result. 
 
14.  Children in schools do not have necessary textbooks. Since independence, the supply of 
free Soviet textbooks has ceased, and the civil war devastated the existing supply. Parents are 
unable to buy books, and MOE lacks budget to provide them. MOE has been struggling to 
address this problem. A rental scheme has been introduced to mobilize additional resources. 
  
15.  Limited and Inefficient Financing. The Government recognizes that tight finances 
pose a major challenge to education development. Public funding for education is generally tied 
to norms such as the number of teachers required according to the curriculum at each grade.

Funds allocated to line items are set rigidly, and transfer of funds across line items is limited. 
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has just introduced unit costs per student to increase flexibility in 
spending. Substantial efforts are now required to implement per-capita funding to enhance

16.  The Government, under its PRSP, plans to gradually increase funding to education from 
2.4% of GDP in 2001 to 3.0% in 2004. However, there are regional disparities due to different 
revenue bases of local governments and an insufficient budget—particularly at the local levels, 
given that over 80% funding for primary and general secondary education comes from local 
budgets—to  address  such  disparities.  A  set  of  strategic  measures  is  needed,  to  increase 
resources and enhance efficient resource use. This includes identifying and reducing system-
wide inefficiencies, identifying and reducing high unit costs, developing alternative cost-effective 
measures  and  means,  streamlining  and/or  rationalizing  the  education  system,  establishing 
“partnerships,” generating income, obtaining a larger proportion of the national budget, and 
ensuring  successful  reform.  Finally,  it  also  requires  reforming  the  incentive  system  and 
providing greater flexibility on expenditure management to education institutions and managers 
at all levels. 
 
17.  In a national policy document, the Concept on Education,5 Tajikistan places high priority 
on reforming and modernizing its education system. The PRSP recognizes that education 
development is central to poverty reduction. Tajikistan has publicly committed itself to the 
Education for All goals and increased educational spending as a percentage of GDP. 
 
18.  Lessons  Learned.  Experience  from  the  ongoing  social  sector  rehabilitation  project 
suggests  that  project  management  needs  careful  design  and  qualified  staff  to  expedite 
implementation  and  maintain  quality  work.  It  also  points  out  the  need  to  support  the 
implementing agency (in this case, MOE), especially when major reforms are involved. Finally, 
higher-level ownership and support is critical for successful implementation. Without appropriate 
salaries, performance-related incentives, training, or on-the-job support, it is difficult to ensure 
good performance and high standards. Effective human resource management at the district 
and  school  levels  requires  sufficient  delegation  of  authority  and  responsibility,  as  well  as 
appropriate  training  with  ongoing  supportive  supervision.  At  the  regional  level,  functional 
analyses will be important in identifying service and staffing needs and in supporting effective 
workforce  planning  and  management.  Many  countries  in  Central  Asia  are  supporting 
educational decentralization, but experience shows this requires a strong information base, 
support for capacity building, and effective monitoring. 
 
19.  Education reform efforts since 1997 provide more lessons. While efforts such as training 
teachers,  developing  and  distributing  textbooks,  involving  parent-teacher  associations,  and 
rehabilitating school buildings have improved the education sector, there is an urgent need to 
consolidate  these  efforts  and  to  construct  a  national  education  system  to  (i)  modernize 
governance and management, and (ii) develop a curriculum that better prepares citizens for this 
century. There is also a need to develop capacity to improve availability and use of information 
to plan and target resources at reducing inequities. The system needs to identify efficiency 
measures, and their linkages within the sector to use resources more effectively, as well as to 
rationalize the education system to ensure sustainable, relevant education post independence. 
Tajikistan’s tight fiscal situation, combined with high adult literacy, provides opportunities to 
mobilize communities for school improvements.

20.  Funding Coordination. A major project strategy is to pursue a unique opportunity to 
collaborate  with  several  other  development  partners  under  the  newly  emerging  funding 
coordination initiative (Appendix 3). Based on existing comparative advantage and experience, 
collaboration is being sought to complement MOE-level TA for capacity building, led by the 
United States Agency for International Development (USAID); school improvement funds and 
teacher training, led by the Aga Khan Foundation; the EMIS, supported by the German Agency 
for Technical Cooperation (GTZ) and the Soros Foundation; textbook development, led by the 
Soros Foundation; community-based EMIS, supported by Save the Children Fund-UK and the 
United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF); and baseline student assessment, supported by 
UNICEF.  The  Education  Sector  Reform  Project  (ESRP)  builds  on  ongoing  initiatives  and 
complements emerging initiatives from other development partners where there is potential for 
synergy.  For  instance,  the  pilot  district  of  Roshkala  already  benefits  from  the  Aga  Khan 
Foundation’s support in social, health, and education services. Similarly, the curriculum and 
textbook development work under the ESRP will be carried out in close collaboration with the 
World Bank’s parallel support to textbook policy. The ESRP also supports MOE’s capacity to 
coordinate funding agencies.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
21.  The goal of the ESRP is to contribute to the Government’s overall strategic goal of 
poverty reduction by improving equitable access to, and completion of, quality primary and 
general secondary education. This goal focuses on girls and vulnerable groups, particularly in 
rural areas. The ESRP’s objective is to support MOE’s education reform program by helping it to 
develop a prioritized, costed National Education Development Framework (NEDF) to improve 
efficiency, equity, and quality in primary and general secondary education.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
22.  The ESRP has three components: (i) system efficiency and management, (ii) equitable 
access and completion, and (iii) quality improvement. The ESRP will have national and pilot 
district components. Pilot components will be implemented in five rural districts: Roshkala, in 
Gorno Badakshan Autonomous Region (GBAR); Kulyab, in Khatlon Region; Ayni and Gornaya 
Matcha, in Sughd Region; and Garm, in RRS. The pilot districts were selected based on the 
level and severity of poverty, the level of infant and maternal mortality, girls’ enrollment rate, and 
proportion of female teachers (Appendix 4). Geographical variation was also considered. The 
ESRP’s goal will have a direct positive impact on Tajikistan’s PRSP, and will target primary and 
general secondary education, with particular focus on girls and vulnerable groups, contributing 
to achievement of key MDGs. Parallel implementation of the ESRP with another in the health 
sector in the same districts will particularly benefit community mobilization, child health, and 
early education.  
 
1.  Component 1: System Efficiency and Management 
23.  Improved system efficiency and improved management are required throughout the 
education system, especially given that the current system is unaffordable. This component 
consists of three subcomponents described in the following paragraphs.

6  
a.  Policy and Planning 
24.  The  policy  and  planning  subcomponent  provides  support  to  the  Department  for 
Education Policy Development (DEPD) in MOE to develop an NEDF. The NEDF will coordinate 
various reform processes toward a broad national education agenda that contributes to national 
developmental  goals  (economic  growth  and  a  vibrant  democracy)  as  well  as  to  specific 
educational targets (increased net enrollment, particularly for girls in grades 10–11; increased 
use of modern pedagogical techniques; more parental control over local educational resources; 
high  expectations  of  all  learners;  better  children’s  health  and  school  readiness;  improved 
efficiency of available resources). While the basic components of a framework were set out in 
an ADB-sponsored workshop (19–21 September 2002), DEPD will develop it to ensure that the 
NEDF informs government and nongovernment activity at all levels. The NEDF will also function 
as a tool to assess the impact of reform, an education investment decision support aid, and a 
dynamic learning device. The NEDF will be the product of a well-informed consultative process 
involving stakeholders at all levels, including parents and community leaders. It will draw from 
the PRSP, build on the education public expenditure review, and be set within a medium-term 
expenditure framework to be supported directly or indirectly by other development partners. The 
NEDF will pull together various analyses and build on the initiatives of the Government and 
development partners. 
 
25.  The ESRP will support MOE in convening four task teams: (i) a financial management 
task team to design structures and systems to improve the efficiency of financial decision 
making;  (ii)  a  pedagogical  renewal  task  team  to  support  curriculum  development,  teacher 
training, and instructional materials; (iii) a management reorganization task team, to design and 
monitor a management reorganization framework of education management responsibilities; 
and (iv) an information and evaluation task team (IETT) to design information systems for 
planning. DEPD will oversee and integrate the work of various task teams, and will develop 
medium- and long-term education development plans derived from the NEDF. The education 
development plans will be outcomes-based, and will contain broad performance indicators to 
allow  for  flexibility  in  implementation  at  local  and  institutional  levels.  The  ESRP,  in  close 
collaboration with development partners, is expected to influence the development of secondary 
legislation (decrees and regulations) and possible primary legislation—to the extent feasible and 
practical—as an effort toward longer-term sustainable development of the education sector 
(Appendix 5).  
 
b.  Information Systems and Monitoring and Evaluation System 
26.  This  subcomponent  provides  for  the  construction  of  a  sound  EMIS,  as  well  as  a 
monitoring and evaluation system (MES) that will (i) provide a basis for improved planning 
systems, (ii) help quantify inequities pertaining to gender and poverty, and (iii) ensure that 
analyzed information is fed back into planning processes and system improvement.  
 
27.  The ESRP will strengthen the EMIS to improve the quality of information available to 
MOE, education departments at regional and district levels, and education institutions. Elements 
will be incorporated into the EMIS to quantify inequities and to support school rationalization, in 
such  a  way  that  the  overall  cost  and  policy  implications  of  school  rationalization  can  be 
examined at various levels throughout the system.  
 
28.  The ESRP provides for the design and implementation of an MES. Standards and 
performance indicators for various key activities (learning, teaching, management, and support) 
and  actors  (pupils,  teachers,  school  directors,  department  heads,  and  deputy  ministers)

7
throughout  the  system  are  key  to  the  success  of  the  MES.  Results  should  also  be 
disaggregated by gender. Various policy documents refer to the need for new standards of 
learning achievement; however, development of a culture of quality standards for other aspects 
of the system is equally important. For example, the ESRP will allow development of new job 
descriptions for teachers and education managers, and standards of expected performance and 
related indicators. Information on achievement in terms of standards and performance indicators 
will be crucial and will drive the overall pedagogical renewal effort. The MES will be designed to 
provide feedback against these standards and indicators, and in this way will give important 
information about the success of the reform process and possible enhancements. It will also 
help IETT to analyze the differential project impacts and provide suggestions on upscaling 
project activities. The crucial challenge in this component is to develop a culture of learning at 
all levels of the system (including parents and MOE staff), by ensuring that level-appropriate 
types and formats of information are available for continued planning. 
 
c.  Management Development 
29.  The  management  development  subcomponent  provides  for  training  for  education 
managers to develop competence in policy and planning, EMIS and MES, pedagogical renewal, 
and financial management (Appendix 6). The management program will be based on a clear 
definition  of  competence,  encapsulated  in  program  outcomes,  assessment  criteria,  and 
performance  requirements.  Credits  will  be  awarded  for  the  successful  completion  of 
management programs, and, with careful attention to the logical combination of topics, such 
credits can be accumulated as qualifications for different categories of education management 
(for  example,  financial  planning).  An  international  academic  institution  will  be  identified  to 
develop 14 management development modules with inputs from key MOE officials, and the 
training will be delivered through a national institution. About 10 MOE managers, 15 regional 
managers,  30  district  managers,  and  300  school  managers  will  receive  management 
development  training.  About  10  officials  will  receive  overseas  training  associated  with  the 
management development program. 
 
2.  Component 2: Increasing Equitable Access and Completion 
30.  The ESRP is designed to increase equitable access to and completion of education, with 
focus on girls and vulnerable groups, using school mapping as a central strategy. Building on 
the EMIS development, a detailed mapping exercise will define the scope of rationalization, 
leading where necessary to the closure of unsustainable schools. The mapping exercise will 
also generate two key rankings of schools in the target districts: a rehabilitation index (para. 32) 
and a poverty index (para. 33). The indexes will be used to allocate school rehabilitation funds 
(SRFs) and school improvement funds (SIFs). The strategy will be supported through school 
community mobilization (para. 34). Together, the two indexes will create an overall index of 
school need. The index of school need, once it has been pilot tested in the target districts, will 
form the basis for policy and planning in the education system as a whole. The funding formulas 
developed by the ESRP will be used to ensure that schools are funded in a manner that reflects 
their needs and the relative cost of addressing the needs, taking into account that rehabilitation 
costs may be greater than quality improvement costs. Crucially, the funding formulas will be 
used to improve the budgeting process. All components will be planned within the information 
for  planning  framework,  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  framework,  and  the  financial 
management framework.

8  
a.  School Mapping 
31.  The school mapping subcomponent supports a comprehensive school- and district-level 
baseline  survey  to  compare  pre-  and  post-project  cases.  Baseline  information  has  two 
dimensions: (i) quantitative, generating hard data on the location, distribution, and physical 
condition of schools; and (ii) qualitative, generating a comprehensive gender-disaggregated 
analysis of learner achievement as well as social and other barriers to schooling. These barriers 
may include factors such as gender discrimination, poverty constraints, transport difficulties, 
climate, and poor health. School mapping will generate various outputs: (i) an analysis of the 
distribution of schools and constraints to access and retention of girls and vulnerable groups, (ii) 
an analysis of school rehabilitation needs and of school poverty at individual schools, and (iii) an 
analysis of learner achievement. District-level mapping will generate a school rationalization 
plan, and will help to rank all schools in terms of poverty and rehabilitation needs. A physical 
survey was already undertaken in Garm (RSS) during project preparation. The UNICEF-Save 
the Children initiative in community-based EMIS will also be a model for this component. The 
experience gained by ADB, Save the Children, and UNICEF will be examined. The component 
will help indicate how school mapping can be replicated nationally to enrich the national EMIS 
(para. 27) and MES (para. 28). 
 
b.  School Rehabilitation 
32.  Through the school mapping exercise (para. 31), schools in target districts will be ranked 
in terms of rehabilitation needs. About 95 schools will be rehabilitated: 40 will receive minor 
rehabilitation  ($10,000  equivalent  per  school),  30  will  see  major  rehabilitation  ($30,000 
equivalent per school), and 25 will have extensions where classrooms are severely damaged 
($10,000 equivalent per school). The index of school rehabilitation will be used to allocate 
weighted and specified SRFs to the districts, or directly to schools with capacity to manage the 
funds. Schools serving poorer populations will be allocated greater amounts. SRFs will be 
allocated particularly for school rehabilitation, and will be tied to a school’s ranking on the 
rehabilitation index. Schools would receive the SRF directly if they have produced a school 
improvement plan (SIP)6 and can demonstrate their capacity to implement it. The evaluation of 
SIPs will be based on simple criteria: it must be the product of a widely consultative effort 
among  school  and  community  stakeholders,  and  there  must  be  mechanisms  to  ensure 
transparency, accuracy, and accountability in financial management. TA will be provided to 
support the overall SIP process at the district and school levels, particularly with respect to 
school mapping, planning, and local procurement. 
 
c.  School Improvement 
33.  The strategy for school improvement is similar to the strategy for school rehabilitation. 
Schools in the target districts will first be ranked in terms of poverty through the school mapping 
exercise (para. 31). The ranking will be based on key factors, including the proportion of girls 
and female teachers, local income levels, child health, and water and sanitation conditions. The 
index of school poverty will be used to allocate SIFs to the districts (or directly to schools if there 
is capacity to manage the funds). The SIFs will be weighted in the same manner as the SRFs 
(para. 32). The evaluation of the SIPs will be based on similar criteria to those applied for the

d.  Community Mobilization  
34.  Under this subcomponent, community-level stakeholders will be encouraged to take 
charge of the educational well-being of their children, empowering them to (i) participate in the 
educational process by developing and implementing SIPs, as well as managing SRFs and 
SIFs; (ii) make demands on the system; (iii) hold the system accountable for results; and (iv) 
appoint people at the village level to support the improvement process. These are major steps 
in democratizing the education system and curbing corruption, as well as contributing to school 
improvement with focus on gender equity, school health, and quality. The ESRP will support 
community mobilization in each pilot district to organize targeted public information campaigns 
supporting equitable access and quality improvement. In many cases, the ESRP will not be the 
only community-level reform effort under way, so synergy of effort and economies of scale must 
be ensured. In each pilot district, a community change agent will be identified to play a major 
role in this regard. The change agent will be accountable to the appointing committee, which will 
comprise  elected  representatives  of  parent-teacher  associations.  In  the  long  term,  funding 
arrangements for change agents will come from SIFs, and village schools can decide whether to 
invest in this strategy or not. 
 
3.  Component 3: Improving Quality Education 
35.  This  component  is  designed  to  improve  the  quality  of  education  through  teacher 
development,  curriculum  development,  and  improved  teaching  and  learning  materials.  Key 
subcomponents are described in the following paragraphs. 
 
a.  Teacher Training 
36.  This subcomponent will draw up a detailed action plan to implement the teacher-training 
element  of  the  pedagogical  renewal  framework  (PRF).  The  action  plan  will  include  (i)  a 
framework of teacher standards to guide the design of accredited pre- and in-service teacher 
training programs; (ii) a teacher appraisal system that will form part of the monitoring and 
evaluation framework (para. 28); (iii) mechanisms to ensure that the results of teacher appraisal 
feed into the district-level EMIS and into planning for improvement; (iv) incentives (monetary 
and nonmonetary) to ensure that teachers who successfully complete in-service training and 
implement the new competencies are rewarded; and (v) strategies to attract and retain more 
female teachers. Provided that all the action plans meet the outcomes set out in the PRF, the 
various districts may pilot different approaches interweaving standards, appraisal, incentives, 
and accredited teacher-training programs, though the standards should be uniform. Over 6,000 
teachers,  including  all  female  teachers  in  primary  and  general  secondary  schools  in  pilot 
districts, will receive in-service training. District-level action plans should be developed in a 
participatory manner, with focus on increasing the numbers of girls in grades 10 and 11 and 
female teachers. The results of the evaluation of the different strategies will feed into the 
refinement  of  the  PRF  and  the  NEDF.  Strategies  for  servicing  remote  rural  areas  will  be 
emphasized.

10  
b.  Curriculum Development 
37.  A detailed action plan will be drawn up and implemented to support the curriculum 
development element of the PRF building on MOE’s new curriculum (2002). The action plan 
should include (i) a framework of competence-based learner achievement standards (generic 
and subject-specific) that will guide the design of the curriculum and of teaching and learning 
materials; (ii) a learner assessment system that will form part of the monitoring and evaluation 
framework (para. 28); (iii) mechanisms to ensure that the results of learner assessments feed 
into the district-level EMIS and into planning for improvement; and (iv) nonmonetary incentives 
to ensure that learner achievement is stimulated continuously and not only rewarded through 
certification. Two core curriculum subjects in grades 5–11 will be renewed to reflect state-of-the-
art teaching and learning practices. As with teacher training, all action plans must meet the 
outcomes set out in the PRF, but the various districts may pilot different approaches provided 
that learner achievement standards are uniform. District-level action plans should be developed 
in a participatory manner, in parallel with plans for teacher training. As with teacher training, the 
results of evaluating the different strategies will support refinements to the PRF and NEDF.  
 
c.  Teaching and Learning Materials 
38.  A policy on teaching and learning materials will be developed as an element of the PRF, 
as well as a strategy for implementation. The policy and strategy will encompass (i) standards 
for  producing  teaching  and  learning  materials,  (ii)  linking  between  standards  of  learner 
achievement and teaching standards, (iii) commissioning and approval systems that eliminate 
possible corruption, (iv) cost-effective production and distribution systems, and (v) mechanisms 
for monitoring and evaluating the quality of teaching and learning materials that feed into the 
monitoring and evaluation framework. Two core curriculum subjects for grades 5–11 will be 
targeted for textbook distribution, which will support MOE’s textbook rental scheme. Results of 
evaluations will help to refine the PRF and NEDF.  
 
C.  Special Features 
39.  At  the  national  level,  the  ESRP  provides  an  inclusive  system  reform  framework 
(Appendix 7). This framework will allow key MOE officials to seek TA to identify priority areas of 
reforms  and  to  address  them  in  line  with  the  Government’s  priorities  through  a  more 
consultative and analytical process. This approach is expected to enhance MOE’s ownership of 
the reform process. 
 
40.  At the district level, the ESRP relies on school mapping information to rank schools 
based on poverty and rehabilitation, including gender equity and school health, an approach 
unique to Tajikistan. This is expected to channel support to the most needy schools (para. 31). 
Support to school improvement plans will strengthen the financing process, and will provide a 
mechanism to link funding to school improvement. 
 
41.  Tajikistan is a transition economy, where the move from rigid central planning to a more 
open  market  environment  has  created  many  challenges  to  education.  To  cope with  these 
changes, the ESRP supports policy and institutional reforms, including (i) reorienting education 
service delivery by strengthening the capacity of schools; (ii) strengthening MOE’s ability to plan 
and  target  resources;  (iii)  refocusing  budget  preparation  from  norm-based  to  per-capita 
allocation; and (iv) promoting accelerated system rationalization. DEPD’s capacity to manage 
education reform will be considerably strengthened.

F.  Implementation Arrangements   
1.  Project Management  
45.  The ESRP will be implemented in parallel with the proposed HSRP in the same five pilot 
districts. The ESRP’s Executing Agency will be the President’s Office, and a deputy prime 
minister will serve as the project coordinator. A national steering committee—chaired by the 
deputy prime minister and comprising senior officials from MOE, the Ministry of Health, MOF, 
and governors of the pilot districts—will be established to coordinate policy reform, address 
implementation bottlenecks, and provide overall project guidance. The steering committee will 
meet quarterly and be responsible for approving the annual project budget and work plans, as 
well as reviewing and advising on implementation. 
 
46.  A project implementation unit (PIU) will be set up at MOE with three full-time staff to 
undertake technical project functions in full consultation with the four task teams (financial 
management, organizational restructuring, pedagogical renewal, and EMIS and MES). The PIU 
will be supported by a project administration unit (PAU) to be shared by PIUs at MOE and the 
Ministry of Health to manage procurement, consultants, training, reports on disbursement, and 
monitoring  of  pilot  districts.  The  PIU,  with  support  from  PAU,  will  organize  quarterly 
implementation review meetings jointly with the task teams. The PIU will engage part-time staff 
as needed. 
 
47.  Each of the five pilot districts will have a district supervisory group, shared by the ESRP 
and HSRP, comprising the district governor, the chief medical doctor at the district hospital, the 
director of the district department of education, two village leaders, two school directors, and 
two doctors or health specialists. The group will coordinate district-level activities and ensure 
synergy between education and health. In each pilot district, the education department will serve 
as the district PIU, comprising a district project coordinator, procurement/civil engineer, and an 
administrator responsible for district-level implementation and day-to-day management. Project 
management and monitoring capacities will be strengthened at the MOE’s PIU, the PAU, and 
the district supervisory group and district PIU through targeted staff training. The implementation 
arrangements, elaborated in Appendix 10, will promote MOE’s ownership of and commitment to 
education reform.  
 
48.  Mobilizing parallel grant funds in response to the Government’s request will result in a 
variety of financing sources and will impose an additional degree of difficulty in implementing 
and coordinating the ESRP. Coordination of external funding agencies must be enhanced to 
complement the roles of the PIU and PAU. 
 
49.  Management  Training  Programs.  Management  development  programs  will  be 
designed and delivered by (i) an international academic institution with experience in education 
management development, (ii) a local public training institute, and (iii) consultants working 
under the relevant components. Key members of task teams will be supported by consultants 
and will receive targeted, short-term, out-of-country training. Management training modules will 
be developed by an international academic institution and will be delivered through a local 
public training institute. 
 
50.  Implementation of SIPs, SIFs, and SRFs. Each school in the pilot district will be invited 
to submit a simple SIP proposal for SRFs and SIFs. The education department, with project TA, 
will review proposals and identify eligible schools. Schools identified to receive SRFs are also 
eligible to receive SIFs for instructional materials for teachers, libraries, chalkboards, and sports

equipment. Each school identified to receive the SIF will be informed officially by the district 
department of education and will sign a letter indicating its contributions and commitment to

IV.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
60.  The purpose of the TA is to provide impetus for building EMIS for informed policy dialog, 
decision-making, and system monitoring. The objectives of the TA are to (i) streamline EMIS at 
the MOE, region, and district levels, (ii) set up EMIS frameworks in the five pilot districts, (iii) 
support a national school census of all primary and general secondary schools, (iv) improve 
decision-making at all levels, and (v) support monitoring and evaluation at the MOE. The TA will 
serve as a central policy tool to improve MOE’s annual planning and budgeting. Baseline data 
will help plan project activities, monitor performance, and measure impacts. The TA will finance 
9  months  of  international  consulting  services  and  70  months  of  domestic  consulting  with 
expertise in EMIS, surveys, and database management. EMIS consultants will work closely with 
the  monitoring  and  evaluation  consultants.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  18  months. 
Appendix 15 provides detailed information on the proposed TA. Consultants will be engaged 
individually according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. For domestic consultants, 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB will be used. 
 
61.  ADB will finance the TA on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The TA is estimated to cost $355,000 equivalent, comprising $238,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $117,000 equivalent in local currency. ADB will provide $300,000 to 
finance the entire foreign currency cost and $62,000 of local currency cost. The Government will 
provide the remaining $55,000 equivalent in kind. 
 
V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
62.  The ESRP will have a positive impact on primary and general secondary education by 
improving efficiency and quality of education and helping to reduce large discrepancies in 
access, particularly for girls and vulnerable groups. The expected impact will be achieved by (i) 
involving school communities in organizing training, and equipping and rehabilitating education 
facilities; (ii) campaigning to improve education quality and relevance; (iii) facilitating an increase 
in and targeting of budget allocation to school education; (iv) enabling pro-poor strategies at the 
district level through poverty indexing that will primarily benefit the lower half of the poorer 
population in five of the poorest districts; and (v) enhancing the capacity of education personnel  
to work for girls and vulnerable groups at all levels. The focus on gender equity and school 
health through community mobilization and school improvement will enhance the children’s 
capacity to attend school regularly and improve their performance. 
 
63.  At the national level, the ESRP will support MOE with the development of an NEDF to 
prioritize education reform and strengthen the EMIS and MES to improve policy analysis and 
annual planning, budgeting, monitoring, and overall decision-making. The management training 
programs will benefit 10 MOE managers, 15 regional managers, 30 district managers, and 300 
school directors, and will contribute to strengthening management competency and capacity at 
all levels. At the district level, about 50% of the 300 schools in five of the poorest districts will 
benefit from SIFs that will help to improve equitable access to better quality primary and general 
secondary education. Over 6,000 teachers, including all female teachers in the pilot districts, will 
also benefit from in-service training in modern teaching methods. About 90,000 school children

16  
in grades 1–11 will have access to better-quality school education. About 50% of the schools in 
the pilot districts will benefit from some form of physical improvement. 
 
B.  Project Risks 
64.  The  ESRP  faces  three  possible  risks,  particularly  in  the  short  term.  Financially, 
successful implementation depends on continuation of regular government financial support to 
the pilot districts (paras. 74 and 75), rationalization of the system, and realization of funding 
increases expected (para. 17). The timely and full release of counterpart funds by MOF is 
another  important  element  in  successful  implementation  (para.  85).  Similarly,  the  financial 
contribution of district departments of education to SIFs is critical to sustain this approach, even 
after the ESRP, and to improve financing to schools.   
 
65.  Successful  implementation  depends  largely  on  MOE’s  capacity  to  plan,  develop, 
implement, and evaluate system reforms, including the establishment of an EMIS. Involvement 
of the President’s Office and shared implementation arrangements with the HSRP based on an 
experienced PAU offset somewhat the complicated implementation arrangements and the risks 
arising from the Government’s reluctance to borrow for training, consulting services, or project 
management (para. 44). Any effort to further reduce the provision for these activities may pose 
a serious risk to implementation. The national steering committee needs to pay close attention 
to and support the strengthening of MOE capacity to implement project activities and associated 
reforms.  
 
66.   The  ESRP  assumes  MOE  is  committed  to  significant  restructuring  of  education 
management. This commitment is expressed in various policy documents, notably the National 
Concept on Education of July 2002 (para. 17). Without such restructuring, inefficiencies will 
endure, and the results of successful pilot projects in the target districts may not contribute to 
systemic reform. The ESRP is expected to lay the foundation for further reform. 
 
C.  Environment 
67.  The ESRP falls under environmental category "C;" i.e., the screening process during 
project preparation identified no adverse environmental impacts. Appendix 16 provides a brief 
summary of the initial environmental assessment. 
 
D.  Social Analysis 
68.  The ESRP aims to increase equity and effectiveness in the provision of educational 
benefits by focusing on five pilot districts disadvantaged by natural disasters, civil strife, poverty, 
and vulnerable minority populations. Women and girls are also a specific focus. The ESRP will 
set up social measures likely to benefit the vulnerable groups, women, and children based on 
comprehensive school mapping in each pilot district. The summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy form is in Appendix 17. 
 
1.  Poverty Impact 
69.  Poverty  remains  Tajikistan’s  central  development  issue.  Tajikistan  was  one  of  the 
poorest republics even before the dissolution of the former Soviet Union, despite large annual 
budget transfers from Moscow. The economic collapse of the early 1990s and subsequent civil 
strife caused poverty to intensify and spread. About 83% of the population was below the

17
poverty line in 1999.7 Poverty rates were high for households with many children, widows with 
small children, the unemployed, people without access to any kind of social safety net (the 
disabled, school dropouts, street children, and the elderly), single pensioners, returnees, and 
internally displaced people. Rural areas have higher and deeper incidences of poverty, and the 
direct incidences of poverty occur in remote mountainous areas where the population is mostly 
very young or elderly. The five pilot districts are considered among the poorest in Tajikistan, and 
the lower half of the population is intended to benefit more from the ESRP than the upper half. 
 
70.  Poverty  manifests  itself  in  different  forms,  and  disproportionately  affects  vulnerable 
groups in the education sector. Meager budgetary allocations to education, as well as formal 
and  informal  charges  at  different  levels,  mean  that  the  lowest  economic  quintile  has  to 
contribute 17.0% of household income to education, compared to just 5.3% for the top quintile. 
Preschool  enrollment,  particularly  of  children  from  poor  households,  has  declined  sharply 
because they are unable to pay, so their children are less well prepared to perform in school. 
The poor have greater difficulty getting textbooks and learning materials because of associated 
charges. Health problems, greater opportunity costs, and inadequate clothing for bad weather 
mean that regular school attendance among the poor has declined, more so in rural areas and 
in upper grades. A gender gap is emerging, particularly at upper and post-secondary levels, with 
a consistent trend across all regions. These analyses will guide poverty indexing and targeting 
under the ESRP. 
 
2.  Women 
71.  Prior to independence, Tajikistan achieved high adult literacy (99% in 1990) and gender 
parity in educational participation. However, in recent years, girls’ enrolment and attendance, 
particularly at the upper secondary level, is lower than boys’. The proportion of female teachers 
has been rising steadily since 1991, and females comprised about 45.7% of the teaching force 
in primary and general secondary education in 2001 (against 37% in 1991). But the decline in 
girls’ enrollment in grades 10 and 11, particularly in remote locations, may limit the pool of 
female  teachers.  Women  in  their  20s  are  slightly  less  educated  than  those  in  their  30s, 
indicating that greater efforts are required to enroll more females, particularly at the upper-
secondary  level.  Women,  when  they  work,  are  concentrated  in  the  lowest-paid  sectors— 
agriculture, education, and health—where wages are insufficient. 
 
72.  The proportion of girls enrolled in grades 10 and 11 in the five project districts is about 
36%, or less than the national average of 38%. The proportion of female teachers is about 35%, 
less  than  the  national  proportion  of  46%.  The  ESRP  will  make  targeted  efforts  to  ensure 
increased enrollment of girls and a greater proportion of female teachers in project schools. 
 
3.  Ethnic Minorities 
73.  The constitution indicates that no person shall be discriminated against on the basis of 
ethnic origin. The constitution also guarantees minorities equal access to education. According 
to some NGOs working in the pilot districts, ethnic minorities are well integrated and enjoy the 
same health and education status, except for the elderly Russian population that receives 
support from NGOs. The ESRP falls under category “C” in terms of minority groups. More 
detailed information on ethnic minorities is provided in Appendix 4.

1.  Project Implementation 
75.  Within 3 months after the loan effective date, a district supervisory group and a district 
PIU will be established in each of the pilot districts, comprising members acceptable to ADB. 
 
76.  Within  3  months  after  the  loan  effective  date,  all  task  teams  at  MOE,  with  staff

2.  Policies 
77.  An EMIS and MES committee will be formed within 3 months of loan effectiveness to 
support the design, development, and implementation of EMIS and MES, and to facilitate policy 
dialog on education reforms.  
 
78.  School mapping will be completed by the end of 2004 in all pilot districts to (i) establish 
baseline information and school ranking; (ii) prepare a school rationalization plan for each pilot 
district  to  improve  efficiency,  equity,  and  environmental  and  sanitation  conditions;  and  (iii) 
ensure targeted support to pilot districts and schools.  
 
79.  Following  school  mapping  results  by  the  end  of  2004,  each  of  the  ESRP  district 
education departments will submit a time-bound action plan to improve girls’ enrollment in 
grades 1–11, with a particular focus on grades 10 and 11, to be supported by the ESRP. 
 
80.  The ESRP support to civil works and SRFs will be based on (i) school mapping results to 
be  made  available  by  the  end  of  2004,  and  (ii)  a  simple  SIP  to  be  submitted  by  each 
participating school to the district department when seeking funds. TA will be provided to 
schools and district departments as necessary for this purpose. 
 
81.  The ESRP support to teacher training will be based on the teacher-training framework 
developed and the training needs identified in the first year. A phased training program will be 
introduced in the second year. 
 
82.  The ESRP support to textbook procurement will be based on the textbook development 
framework and development process agreed to during the first year. Two core subjects for 
grades 5–11 will be supported.

83.  The  Government  will  ensure  timely  provision  of  necessary  government  counterpart 
funds. The project director, assisted by the PIU and PAU, will prepare and submit an annual 
budget plan in time for MOF’s budgeting process in November. The PIU and PAU will also 
submit quarterly reports to the MOF on the counterpart requirements for the next quarter. 
 
84.  The share of public expenditure for education will rise from the current 2.5% of GDP to 
3% as stipulated by PRSP, but in any event this shall be achieved by 2008.

4.  In-service teacher training is insignificant, and more than 50% of the students graduating 
from pre-service teacher training do not enter the profession because of very low salaries and 
preference  for  other  professions.  Teacher  salaries  increased  in  2002,  but  many  teachers 
supplement their salaries by teaching more than one shift. Similarly, many experienced and 
qualified teachers have left the profession, resulting in about 20% of the teachers with no 
training in 2000 compared to 9% in 1991, and 62% of the teachers with university training in 
2000 compared to 77% in 1991. 
 
5.  Internal and external efficiency of the education system is considered low. A smaller 
proportion of students is completing the general secondary cycle. A pupil-teacher ratio of 15:1 
and a teaching-to-non-teaching staff ratio of 1:1.5 are considered very low and indicate room for 
significant improvement. Lower participation of females (less than 40% of total enrollment) 
beyond the basic level needs to be improved. Improvement in student assessment is critical to 
improve efficiency of available resources. 
 
6.  Attendance rates have particularly declined in primary and general secondary education 
to around 80%, but more sharply in upper secondary education, with adverse implications on 
quality. Children’s attendance has declined mainly because they lack textbooks or learning 
materials, have health problems (malnutrition, anemia), experience rising opportunity costs, and 
other  problems  associated  with  poverty.  More  than  40%  of  parents  have  expressed 
dissatisfaction over the status of education quality.1 The current generation in Tajikistan is at risk 
of receiving a poorer education than the previous one. 
 
7.  In line with the Government’s policy stipulations, the ADB-supported education sector 
review proposes key reforms, including (i) constructing a national education system, (ii) moving 
away  from  the  command-and-control  mode  of  educational  delivery  that  characterized  the 
previous centralized system, (iii) modernizing system governance and management, and (iv) 
developing a curriculum to better prepare its citizens for this century. A key challenge is that 
Tajikistan can ill afford to run the system it inherited at independence. Despite funding agency 
driven reform efforts over the last 5 years, Tajikistan still faces similar problems: infrastructural 
ruin  and  neglect,  displaced  communities,  institutional  breakdown,  a  brain  drain  of  highly 
qualified experts, the emergence of a shadow economy that rivals the “official” economy, and 
the deterioration of public services. More recently, external funding agencies in the education 
sector have begun to improve coordination to support the Government. 
 
8.  Tajikistan now faces a formidable task of reforming its education system. Problems 
adequately addressed in small-scale pilot projects are yet to be taken to scale, while the rest of 
the system confronts major challenges. However, opportunities do exist. The Government has 
pressed forward with the formal adoption of a poverty reduction strategy that recognizes the 
educational development as central to relieving poverty. Tajikistan has publicly committed itself 
to education and educational spending as a percentage of GDP.

DIALOGUE FOR EDUCATION REFORM 
 
A.    Background and Rationale 
 
1.  In order to establish an effective educational management information system (EMIS), it 
is important to address the following issues:  
 
(i)  Detailed  information  on  education  institutions,  particularly  on  schools,  is 
consolidated at the district level, and again at the city/region level before being 
submitted to the Ministry of Education (MOE). This means that the MOE has 
access only to broad averages and totals for planning purposes. While it is 
possible to analyze the distribution of resources across districts, it is not easy to 
analyze this distribution below the district level. The capacity of the MOE to 
monitor equity in education, and to plan accordingly, is therefore weak. 
 
(ii)  There  is  an  almost  exclusive  emphasis  on  quantitative  information  such  as 
learner  numbers  per  grade.  There  is  little  or  no  qualitative  information  on 
important factors such as quality of education management, quality of teaching, 
or learner performance.  
 
(iii)  Effective  use  of  data  for  planning  is  poor.  For  example,  information  on  the 
disparities  in  expenditure  by  region  and  by  district  is  not  used  to  correct 
disparities. Information gathered by inspectors and methodologists is not used to 
design retraining programs for teachers. Information on the quality of school 
management is not used to design training programs for school principals and 
parents’ committees; indeed, few such programs exist. 
 
(iv)  Data exists in diverse locations within different levels of the system and the MOE. 
This data is not integrated to generate coherent strategies and plans. 
B.    Objectives 
 
2.  The  purpose  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  to  provide  impetus  in  building 
management  information  systems  for  informed  policy  dialog  and  decision-making.  The 
objectives of the TA are to (i) streamline EMIS at the MOE, region, and district levels, (ii) set up 
EMIS frameworks in the five pilot districts, (iii) support a national school census of all primary 
and general secondary schools, (iv) improve decision-making at all levels, and (v) support 
monitoring and evaluation at the MOE. The TA will serve as a central policy tool to improve 
MOE’s annual planning, budgeting, and system monitoring. Baseline data will help plan project 
activities, monitor performance, and measure impacts.  
   
C.  Scope and Methodology 
 
3.  The  project  design  contains  a  central  emphasis  on  systemic  reform.  The  Project 
provides for the development of a National Education Development Framework (NEDF). The 
NEDF  will  ultimately  set  standards  and  specify  outcomes  for  system  and  management 
efficiency, for access and equity, and for pedagogical renewal. The framework will also specify 
the types of system change that are required; for example, changes in systems like budgeting 
and structures (reorganization of system management).

such  as  financial  management,  management  reorganization,  and  pedagogical  renewal.

B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification 
 
About 83% of the population lives below the poverty line. About 341,800 people, or 5% of the total 
population, live in the five pilot districts of whom over 83% (more than 284,000) live below the poverty 
line. About 90,000 students are enrolled in 298 schools and about 20,000 school-age children are either 
out of school or do not attend school regularly. The five pilot districts are considered poorer than average 
based on the level and severity of poverty (poverty rating developed by World Bank for all districts), the 
level of infant and maternal mortality, the proportion of girls’ enrollment, and the proportion of female 
teachers in schools. 
 
Through school mapping, the ESRP will identify factors inhibiting access to and regular attendance at 
schools to identify and target support to out-of-school children and those not attending schools regularly. 
Regular school attendance has declined, particularly among the poor and more so in rural areas and 
upper grades. These factors may include gender barriers, health problems, greater opportunity costs, and 
other  problems  associated  with  poverty.  A  poverty  index  and  a  school  rehabilitation  index  will  be 
developed to rank all schools into four quartiles.  
 
The ranking of schools based on poverty and school conditions is designed to target the lower half of the 
poorest population. About 45,000 students studying in about 150 schools falling in the lower half of the 
poverty index will benefit more from the ESRP. Similarly, about 20,000 school-age children who are out of 
school or not attending schools regularly will benefit from improved access to schooling. This will help 
local governments responsible for primary and general secondary education to plan better and target 
resources. This will also help to target the poor who can ill afford textbooks and learning materials.

C.  Gender and Development   
For the first time in many years, women in the 20-30 age group are less educated than those in 30-40 
age group, indicating that girls in recent years have received less education. Although Tajikistan had 
achieved gender parity in education, this is now threatened. While girls’ enrollment up to grade 9 is 
slightly less than that of boys, it drops significantly to 38% in grades 10 and 11 nationally, and to 36% in 
pilot districts. While national attendance is around 80% in basic education, girls’ attendance is estimated 
to be less. Unless this trend is rectified soon, the situation may deteriorate further. The ESRP will directly 
or indirectly benefit more than 37,000 girls enrolled in grades 1-11 in project schools. Over 14,000 girls 
estimated to be out of school in project districts are expected to benefit from improved access to schools. 
The ESRP will target girls to ensure that their enrollment and attendance in primary and general 
secondary schools increases by 10-20% in pilot districts, with particular emphasis in grades 10 and 11.

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Macroeconomic Context 
 
1.  A  high  debt  burden,  inefficient  tax  collection, and  the  increasing  importance  of the 
informal economy have contributed to economic decline in Tajikistan. Tajikistan is one of the 
poorest countries in the world, with per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of US$162 in 
2001. Although about 83% of the population remains below the poverty line and unemployment 
is estimated as high as 30%,1 Tajikistan's human development index ranking (112 in 2002) 
remains high compared to other developing countries because of its historical achievement in 
social development. 
 
2.  Low  levels  of  public  expenditure  on  education  are  partially  explained  by  poor 
government capacity to raise tax revenue. Total revenue from tax is around 14% of GDP, which 
is low for a developing country. 
 
B.  Consideration of Design Alternatives and Cost Effectiveness 
 
3.  There  is  a  firm  economic  rationale  to  justify  public  investment  in  human  capital  to 
enhance the earning potential and social benefits. Global studies indicate high rates of return on 
investment in education; the highest returns are in primary education, with rates of return ROR 
above 20%. Secondary education sees ROR above 15% in low income countries.2 
 
4.  Three scenarios were considered to analyze the cost-effectiveness of the ESRP: (i) 
keeping  the  status  quo,  (ii)  increasing  the  education  budget  without  significant  systemic 
investment or change, and (iii) making the investments as planned in this proposal. The first 
alternative was rejected because all available analyses indicate that the current situation is 
deteriorating to the detriment of many school age children. The second alternative was also 
rejected because the system requires major reforms to make it sustainable; for example, if all 
the currently prescribed textbooks were distributed to all school children, this item alone would 
consume all the education resources. The third alternative is therefore being pursued. 
 
5.  The third alternative was further analyzed under three alternatives. First, an investment 
loan modality was proposed since the country has begun to stabilize following the protracted 
civil war, there is a need to move away from emergency-type operations, and there is a need to 
build on different initiatives from different agencies, including coordination mechanisms. The 
environment is not yet appropriate for program- or sector development program-type operations 
since  it  is  first  critical  to  establish  a  deeper  understanding  of  the  sector,  develop  initial 
information base, and build institutional capacity, and establish good donor coordination before 
embarking  on  more  comprehensive  policy  reforms.  The  investment  modality  proposes  to 
support  some  of  key  elements  (national  education  development  framework  [NEDF],  donor 
coordination,  piloting  of  school  reforms,  information  base),  which  would  facilitate  other 
modalities in the future. Initial donor coordination is already emerging. 
 
6.  Second, project components are packaged by national and district levels to ensure cost-
effective use of resources. Systemic reforms are necessary at the national level, whereas 
district-level investments involve direct interventions at the district, school, and community levels

C.  Fiscal Impact 
 
8.  The  Government  will  finance  about  20%  of  the  ESRP  cost.  The  total  ESRP  cost, 
inclusive  of  taxes,  duties,  contingencies,  and  interest  charges,  is  $9.38  million  over 
approximately 5 years. A financial sustainability analysis was done to evaluate the impact of the 
ESRP  on  the  government  budget  (Table  A18).  Based  on  economic  development  and 
expenditure trends, projections were made to assess the annual recurrent expenditure as a 
result of the project investment so that the Government is presented with a clear funding 
commitment. Although education expenditures increased substantially during the last 3 years, 
projections were  conservatively  made  under  the  following  assumptions:  (i)  maintenance  of 
education expenditure at over 3% of GDP and 17% of state expenditure throughout the project 
period; and (ii) incremental recurrent costs after the ESRP will be maintained at about 20% of 
project costs (to decrease gradually). 
 
9.  Of the total ESRP cost of $9.38 million, the Government will finance about $1.88 million.  
The Government’s annual share in ESRP costs will average around $310,000 equivalent, which 
is about 0.91% of the average annual projected education budget of about $34.4 million. The 
recurrent costs to be borne by the Government during the project period are estimated at 
$200,000  per  year  and  include  (i)  operating  expenses  of  project  implementation,  and  (ii) 
operating and maintaining renovated school facilities and equipment.  Based on projections, the 
resulting impact of the project on total education expenditure is only 0.1%; and about 1.1% and 
1.4% respectively on general education budget expenditures and local expenditures. Assuming 
the education spending is maintained, the budgetary impact of the estimated annual recurrent 
costs during and after project implementation is minimal. In parallel, the World Bank will provide 
a $20 million loan (of which $7 million is grant) to implement reforms in seven pilot districts.  The 
United States Agency for International Development  and Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische 
Zusammenarbeit (German Agency for Technical Cooperation, GTZ) will extend $5 million and 
$2 million respectively during the next 2–3 years. These external fund sources average over 
12% of education budget expenditures during the project period. Recurrent costs of externally 
funded  projects,  on  the  other  hand,  average  about  2.1%  and  1.2%,  respectively,  of  the

education budget expenditures during and after the project period, and appear manageable 
over the medium term. 
 
10.  The  ESRP  is  designed  to  minimize  recurrent  costs  for  the  Government  and  the 
community. The improvement of the quality and management support systems under the ESRP 
is intended to improve efficiency of the education system. The development of appropriate and 
improved system will result in an efficient use of resources and an effective delivery of services. 
The costs associated with system development are one-time costs to support reforms, and 
therefore the incremental costs from the ESRP are negligible and sustainable. Although school 
rehabilitation and school funds are being financed, sustainability is being ensured through 
commitments  from  the  local  community  (particularly  parent-teacher  associations)  and  local 
government, with support from stronger district departments. 
 
D.  Education Sector 
 
11.  A sharp decline in the economy following Tajikistan’s independence in 1991 has had a 
serious impact on social-sector financing. The sharp decline in financing to education from over 
11% of GDP in 1991 to around 2.4% in 2001 and the severe damage inflicted to the education 
infrastructure during the protracted civil strife have eroded past achievements. Tajikistan cannot 
afford  the  education  system  of  its  past.  Since  the  system  is  making  efforts  to  align  with 
democracy and an emerging market economy, serious care is needed to adopt an efficient, 
sustainable approach to financing. While there is a need to increase resources for education, it 
is equally important to streamline structural problems. A major project objective is to help the 
Government to move in this direction by laying the foundation for a longer-term financing 
framework.  The  design  comprises  components  that  support  management  and  technical 
efficiency to make investment more affordable and sustainable. 
 
12.  From 2000 to 2002, the social sector absorbed over a third of the total government 
expenditure. The share of social spending in total state expenditures grew from about 34% in 
2000  (4.7%  of  GDP)  to  42%  (5.9%  of  GDP)  in  2002,  indicating  the  Government’s  rising 
commitment to improving social services. After significant declines in the mid-1990s, education 
spending as a share of total state expenditures has increased steadily from 15.3% in 2000 to 
17.6% in 2002. Per capita spending grew from $2.86 to $4.34 during the same period. It is 
projected that government and per capita spending will reach 18.9% and $4.95 respectively in 
2003.  By international comparison, however, Tajikistan’s annual education spending as a share 
of GDP has been the lowest in Central Asia at around 2.5% in 2001. 
 
13.  Private expenditure in education is about 50% of the total expenditure, with almost all 
families spending some money on education, the bulk of it at the tertiary level.3 Following the 
Law on Education (1994), several private schools and universities have been established but 
private  enrolment  is  only  about  1%.  Given  the  tight  fiscal  scenario  and  inability  of  the 
Government  to  increase  allocations  significantly,  private  funding  is  needed.  Efforts  are 
necessary to target public resources to children from poor families at all levels and to make 
financing more transparent to improve quality and equity in education.
